title: Camille Jordan
text:
Marie Ennemond Camille Jordan (; 5 January 1838 – 22 January 1922) was a French mathematician, known both for his foundational work in <a href="group%20theory">group theory</a> and for his influential "Cours d'analyse".
Biography.
Jordan was born in <a href="Lyon">Lyon</a> and educated at the <a href="%C3%89cole%20polytechnique">École polytechnique</a>. He was an engineer by profession; later in life he taught at the École polytechnique and the <a href="Coll%C3%A8ge%20de%20France">Collège de France</a>, where he had a reputation for eccentric choices of notation.
He is remembered now by name in a number of results:
Jordan's work did much to bring <a href="Galois%20theory">Galois theory</a> into the mainstream. He also investigated the <a href="Mathieu%20group">Mathieu group</a>s, the first examples of <a href="sporadic%20group">sporadic group</a>s. His "Traité des substitutions", on <a href="permutation%20group">permutation group</a>s, was published in 1870; this treatise won for Jordan the 1870 <a href="Poncelet%20Prize">"prix Poncelet"</a>. He was an Invited Speaker of the <a href="International%20Congress%20of%20Mathematicians">ICM</a> in 1920 in <a href="Strasbourg">Strasbourg</a>.
The <a href="asteroid">asteroid</a> <a href="25593%20Camillejordan">25593 Camillejordan</a> and are named in his honour.
Camille Jordan is not to be confused with the <a href="geodesist">geodesist</a> <a href="Wilhelm%20Jordan%20%28geodesist%29">Wilhelm Jordan</a> (<a href="Gaussian%20elimination">Gauss–Jordan elimination</a>) or the physicist <a href="Pascual%20Jordan">Pascual Jordan</a> (<a href="Jordan%20algebra">Jordan algebra</a>s).
